Enrica Detragiache

Last Updated: December 13, 2019
  • Background
  • IMF Publications
  • Non-IMF Publications
  • All
Expand All
Collapse All

Enrica Detragiache is a Deputy Director in the European Department of the IMF overseeing surveillance work on several advanced countries including Germany, France, and the UK. She has been IMF mission chief for Germany (2014-2017) and Austria and Switzerland (2011-2014). She has also worked in the IMF Research Department in and the IMF Institute. Before joining the Fund, she was on the faculty in the Economics Department at Johns Hopkins University. Throughout her career, she authored several papers on a wide range of topics, including banking and financial crises, corporate finance, labor migration, and development economics. Her research has been published in major academic journals, such as the American Economic Review, the Journal of Finance, the Journal of Monetary Economics, the Journal of Development Economics, and the Journal of Money, Credit, and Banking. She holds a Ph.D. in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania and an undergraduate degree in Economics from the University of Turin, Italy.

Email: edetragiache@imf.org

Fluent In: French, Italian.

Education:

BA, Economics University of Turin, 1983

PhD. Economics, University of Pennsylvania, 1988


Referee Activities:

American Economic Review, Journal of Finance, Quarterly Journal of Economics, Review of Financial Studies, Journal of International Economics, Journal of Financial Intermediation, Journal of Money, Credit and Banking, Economic Journal, Journal of Development Economics, Review of Economic and Statistics, European Economic Review, and others.


Current Position:

Deputy Director, European Department (EUR), IMF


Other Professional Positions:

Johns Hopkins University: 1988-95, Assistant Professor, Economics Department

Innocenzo Gasparini Institute of Economic Research, Milan, Italy, 1992-93, Fellow.

World Bank, 1990, Visiting Scholar.

Fondazione Luigi Einaudi, Turin, Italy, 1983-84, Research Fellow.


Teaching:

International Monetary Economics

International Trade

Development Economics


IMF Career:

Assistant Director, European Department, 2013-16 (Mission chief: Germany)

Advisor, European Department, 2011-13 (Mission chief: Austria, Switzerland)

Advisor, IMF Institute, 2009-11

Chief, European Division, IMF Institute, 2006-08

Deputy Chief, Financial Studies Division, Research Department, 2003-06

Senior Economist, European I Department, 2000 -03

Senior Economist, Research Department, 1999-2000

Economist, Research Department, IMF, 1995-99


Work in progress:

A European Minimum Wage: Implications for Poverty and Macroeconomic Imbalances (Christian Ebeke, Davide Malacrino, Florian Misch, La-Bhus Fah Jirasavetakul, Koralai Kirabaeva, Ben Park, and Yu Shi)

Enrica Detragiache is a Deputy Director in the European Department of the IMF overseeing surveillance work on several advanced countries including Germany, France, and the UK. She has been IMF mission chief for Germany (2014-2017) and Austria and Switzerland (2011-2014). She has also worked in the IMF Research Department in and the IMF Institute. Before joining the Fund, she was on the faculty in the Economics Department at Johns Hopkins University. Throughout her career, she authored several papers on a wide range of topics, including banking and financial crises, corporate finance, labor migration, and development economics. Her research has been published in major academic journals, such as the American Economic Review, the Journal of Finance, the Journal of Monetary Economics, the Journal of Development Economics, and the Journal of Money, Credit, and Banking. She holds a Ph.D. in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania and an undergraduate degree in Economics from the University of Turin, Italy.

Email: edetragiache@imf.org

Cross-Country Empirical Studies of Systemic Bank Distress: A Survey (with A. Demirgüç-Kunt), National Institute Economic Review, No. 192, pp. 68-83, April 2005.

Deposit Insurance and Moral Hazard (with A. Demirgüç-Kunt), in The Financial Safety Net: Costs, Benefits, and Implications for Regulation, Proceedings of the 37th Annual Conference on Bank Structure and Competition, Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, May 2001.

How Extensive is the Brain Drain? (with W. Carrington), Finance and Development, June 1999, reprinted in the Journal of Social, Political, and Economic Studies, 24: 163-71, 1999; also IMF Working Paper 98/102, July 1998.

Financial Liberalization and Financial Fragility (with A. Demirgüç-Kunt), in B. Pleskovic and J.E. Stiglitz (Eds.) Annual World Bank Conference on Development Economics 1998, (The World Bank, Washington, DC), 1999, reprinted in G. Caprio, P. Honohan, and J. E. Stiglitz (Eds.), Financial Liberalization: How Far, How Fast?, (New York: Cambridge University Press), 2001 and in Issues in the Frontier of International Financial Regulation (China Financial Publishing House), 2002 (in Chinese).

Analytical Aspects of the Debt Problems of Highly Indebted Poor Countries (with S. Claessens, R. Kanbur, and P. Wickham), in Z. Iqbal and R. Kanbur (eds.), External Finance for Low Income Countries, (Washington: International Monetary Fund), 1997.

“Debt Moratorium” and “Debt Forgiveness”, entries in The New Palgrave Dictionary of Money and Finance, P. Newman, M. Milgate, and J. Eatwell (eds.) (London: Macmillan Press), 1992.

Confidence Crises and Public Debt Management: A Discussion, in Capital Markets and Debt Management, M. Draghi and R. Dornbusch (eds.), (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press), 1990.
